title: Day of the Dead in San Jose
text:
Posted: 10/25/2015 04:35:36 PM PDT Updated: 10/26/2015 05:12:54 AM PDT 
SAN JOSE -- Hundreds of Day of the Dead celebrants, many of them wearing happy masks of death and elegant costumes fit to be buried in, marched and frolicked Sunday in one of the Bay Area's largest interpretations of the ancient Mexican religious rite. "It's a celebration of the lives of people who are no longer here," said Arlene Sagun, head of the San Jose Multicultural Artists Guild. "It's not morbidity that we're after." 
Dressed nothing like Halloween zombies, vampires or Easter bunnies, these celebrants followed Aztec dancers in a procession through downtown streets to San Jose State University. A solemn blessing of an outdoor altar decorated with photos of loved ones and offerings of maize was followed by an Americanized, but not yet trivialized or commercialized, version of a custom that started thousands of years. Aztec dancers from the group Mictlan dance before the Dead procession from City View Plaza to San Jose State in San Jose, Calif. on Sunday, Oct. 15, 2015. (Josie Lepe/ Bay Area News Group) ( Josie Lepe ) 
Many historians believe that Los Dias de los Muertos actually began as a harvest ritual that predated the Aztecs. The ancients believed that only the dead could speak to the gods, and their astrology told them that mid-autumn offered the thinnest membrane between Earth and the afterlife. By offering the bounty of harvest, the people believed the spirits of their loved ones might put in a good word for them to the gods. 
Sunday's procession and festival showed that Day of the Dead has clearly evolved into something else in 21st century Silicon Valley. For example, it included a Filipino dance group, belly dancers and celebrants sporting genuine dreadlocks. Ever since the resurrection of Day of the Dead celebrations in the United States during the 1960s, Sagun said, Mexican-Americans have infused the observances with bicultural flair and even politics. Sagun's nonprofit arts group has organized the festival for most of the past 18 years. 
"When we first started we couldn't get anyone to pay attention," she said. "Now it seems like everybody wants to be a part of it."
